questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Obadiah 1:1-11 aloud, paying attention to the contrast between Edom's pride and God's judgment.
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'the pride of your heart' (v3) and the contrast with God's judgment
Pay attention to the emotional tone of Edom's arrogance: 'Who will bring me down to the ground?' (v3)
The imagery of 'soaring aloft like the eagle' (v4) and 'from there I will bring you down' (v4)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, summarize WHO (Edom) is being judged, WHAT (God's judgment on Edom), WHERE (Edom's actions against Judah), and WHY (Edom's pride and violence).
tips: Include Edom's role as the one who stood aloof and let strangers carry off Judah's wealth (v6)
Note the specific consequence: Edom will be cut off forever (v5) and become like stubble (v11)
Mention the contrast between Edom's destruction and the deliverance in Mount Zion (v10)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Edom's arrogance (v3), the imagery of being brought down (v4), or the contrast in v11.
tips: Edom's boastful declaration: 'Who will bring me down to the ground?' (v3) is a powerful example of pride that leads to downfall
The contrast in v11: 'The house of Jacob shall be a fire, and the house of Joseph a flame, and the house of Esau stubble' is a vivid metaphor for God's judgment on Edom and blessing on Judah
The promise that in Mount Zion there will be escape (v10) offers hope amidst the judgment

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Obadiah trying to communicate to Edom/Judah through this passage?
tips: Obadiah warns Edom that their pride and violence against Judah will lead to total destruction, but also points to the future deliverance for God's people in Mount Zion
The passage emphasizes that God's judgment is just and will come upon those who oppose His people, while His blessing is reserved for the faithful
This prophecy serves as a reminder that even in the midst of judgment, God's people in Zion will be protected

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are confusing? The identity of Edom as the enemy of Judah? The meaning of 'the day of the LORD'? The symbolism of 'stubble'?
tips: Edom's historical role: In the ancient Near East, Edom was a nation that was often in conflict with Judah (the southern kingdom of Israel). This passage refers to Edom's past actions of violence again
'The day of the LORD' (v8) refers to God's day of judgment, not a specific future event but a time when God's wrath will be poured out on all nations
The image of 'stubble' (v11) symbolizes something that is burned away and destroyed, while the 'fire' and 'flame' represent the active, enduring blessing of God's people

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How does this passage challenge us to respond? Tie to the theme of 'pride leading to destruction' (v3) or 'the day of the LORD is near' (v8).
tips: Consider a time when you've been proud and how it might have led you to act against others
Pray for humility and a heart that seeks God's judgment rather than others' downfall
Commit to not rejoicing when others face trouble (v7) and to stand with those in need

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray about Edom's judgment and the promise of deliverance in Mount Zion.
tips: Thank God for His judgment on pride and for the promise of deliverance for His people
Pray for humility in your own life and for the strength to avoid taking pleasure in others' suffering
Ask God to help you be a refuge for others, like Mount Zion
